item.title: Big Boy
item.description:
In the local tavern, you could always find Iron. Raised by the elderly on the outskirts of the Hive, he dressed and cut his hair like an old man, with innocent, chubby, rosy cheeks‚Äîhence the nickname “Big Boy.” He was as big as a soldier, though he wasn‚Äôt assigned as one, and was gentle despite his imposing size. Proud and passionate about his people’s history and culture, he was often seen singing anthems or playing melodies on the war horn he always wore around his neck. His songs would echo through the tavern amid the noise of chatter, laughter, and clinking glasses: “Pon pon pon pon,” he‚Äôd cheerfully boom. When asked, he‚Äôd share his controversial views, which were regularly challenged. They all knew what he was, and so did he, but he treated everyone with kindness.

One day, using his horn as a drinking vessel, he told Fire how meeting a Flea People music teacher had softened his views: “I-I-I‚Äôd still r-r-respect him more if he were Hive People, though.” Despite their differences, they coexisted peacefully. Big Boy always struggled to find a girlfriend.

item.title: Re-Entering the Hive
item.description:
As Fire waited in line to re-enter the Hive, he spotted Boulder among the guards on duty. Assigned by birth as a soldier, Boulder had been raised alongside him, though they‚Äôd always had a distant relationship. Fed a different diet than the rest, Boulder was much bigger and tougher-looking. Fire hated his arrogant, overconfident, perpetually-in-challenge-mode face. He would have much rather met someone he didn‚Äôt know.

“Raise your arms!” Boulder said, holding a club in his right hand and avoiding eye contact.

‚ÄúC‚Äômon, we‚Äôve known each other since we were larvae,‚Äù Fire replied.

‚ÄúFor all I know, you could be a stinky flea person in disguise. Raise your arms!‚Äù

‚ÄúSeriously, dude?‚Äù Reluctantly, Fire did as ordered. With his left arm, Boulder yanked Fire‚Äôs arm up even higher, then hunched down and took a big, deep sniff of Fire‚Äôs left armpit. ‚ÄúTurn around,‚Äù he said, sniffing Fire‚Äôs right armpit next. ‚ÄúYuck!‚Äù he exclaimed with disgust. ‚ÄúAlright, you‚Äôre one of us. You may come inside.‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks,‚Äù Fire said, glaring at him with piercing eyes after the unnecessary, humiliating ordeal. As he passed through, Boulder looked up with a barely contained smirk, his hands placed behind his back, like a soldier at ease.

item.title: Owl People
item.description:

“The owl people feel comfortable when they are surrounded by things that remind them of their past,” the guide said. “They can only look back because they see no future,” she concluded.

item.title: Tattooless Tattooer
item.description:

Sitting with his back to the bar, Water offered Fire some of his Queen’s Reserve honeydew liquor. Fire accepted out of politeness and sat beside him, his stomach churning. Although Water was a familiar figure, they hadn‚Äôt spoken before, and Fire struggled to find a topic.

‚ÄúYou do tattoos for a living, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúYup,‚Äù Water said confidently, placing a cigarette in his mouth.

‚ÄúSo how come‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre wondering why I don‚Äôt have any tattoos, aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù

‚Äú‚Ä¶Yeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs okay; lots of people ask me about it,‚Äù he lit his cigarette. ‚ÄúBesides their enchantments, tattoos are typically used as intimidation tactics, right?‚Äù He exhaled smoke. ‚ÄúPeople go for the mean look.‚Äù He took a longer drag, his eyes narrowing. ‚ÄúGuess what frightens me the most.‚Äù

‚ÄúGee, I don‚Äôt kn‚Äî‚Äù

item.title: The Fall of the Tomato Civilization
item.description:
Meanwhile, in Some Dimension…

As I wandered through eerie ruins, I spotted a red figure in the distance. I waved, and they waved back, so I approached. He had a long beard, a staff, and looked like a dried tomato. I asked, “What’s up?”

He began a story about how green tomatoes once played there, but a disagreement over whether to say “to-MAY-toh” or “to-MAH-toh” tore the community apart. Friends became enemies, and civil war broke out. “Cherries were the first to go,” he lamented. The real twist? The leaders, who fueled the conflict, were secretly running a ketchup business‚Äîand were the same person, disguised with a fake mustache.

I asked, “So, what’s the correct pronunciation?”

“We still don’t know,” he replied, “Maybe we never will.”

item.title: The Wallet
item.description:
Fire found a wallet lying on the ground. “Sir, is this yours?” he called out to a scruffy-looking guy who was glancing around nervously.

The man looked left and right before responding, “…Yes?” he said hesitantly.

Fire smirked. “Oh, there‚Äôs an ID in here…” He pulled it out, holding it up next to the man‚Äôs face for a moment, clearly showing that the two didn’t match at all. “Are you… Blibers Flobers?”

The guy fidgeted, avoiding eye contact. “Yes, haha, that’s me! Good ol’ Blibers!” he replied, his voice a little too high-pitched.

“Hey, aren’t you the one responsible for that big disaster everyone is talking about?” Fire probed, raising an eyebrow.

The man started sweating. “Oohpsi-doopsie, that was me! Don’t tell anyone, alright? Now, just give my wallet back, haha!”

Fire chuckled. “Ha, gotcha! I made this name up.”

Just then, an officer strolled over, hands behind his back. It was Boulder, who was on duty that day. “Hey, what’s happening here?”

“Oh, I’m glad you’re here,” Fire replied. “We just found this wallet, and we’re trying to track down the owner.”

Boulder glanced at the ID. “Let me see.” After a quick inspection, he snorted. “What an ugly face. Good luck in your next life.” He then pocketed the cash before handing the wallet back to Fire.

“Good luck with your quest, sir,” the officer said with a dismissive wave as he walked away, still looking up at the sky.

item.title: Wings of Doom
item.description:
On a hot summer night, Fire ventured into the heart of the forest, searching for Wind at the place where they had promised to meet after their metamorphosis. Fire had always thought of Wind as a younger brother, and it had been four years since they‚Äôd last seen each other. Both had recently gone through their pupal stage, a time of transformation that all Hive People undergo. The air was thick with anticipation; Fire could hear only the gentle rustling of leaves and the sound of his own footsteps through the vegetation. Soon, however, he heard a faint sound‚Äîa cry echoing through the trees. Fire called out for Wind several times, but only silence responded.

As Fire walked deeper into the woods, shimmering rays of light began to pierce the darkness. He called again, only to hear a desperate voice pleading, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt come! Stay away!‚Äù Concerned, Fire replied, ‚ÄúWhy? Are you hurt?‚Äù Ignoring Wind‚Äôs frantic warnings, he pressed on.

In rare cases, some Hive People develop two pairs of beautiful, colorful wings after their second metamorphosis, known as the ‚ÄúWings of Doom.‚Äù Once considered a bad omen, those who possessed these wings were often sacrificed in rituals. Over time, however, the Hive People came to accept this phenomenon, gradually learning to appreciate its mysterious qualities.

At the edge of a calm river, Fire finally spotted him‚Äîhunched over, hands clasped over his head, enormous, radiant wings emerging from his back and reflecting in the water. Dazzled and captivated, Fire called out, ‚ÄúYour wings! They‚Äôre incredible! Absolutely breathtaking!‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt look at me!‚Äù Wind cried. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre disgusting! Hideous! I hate them!‚Äù His voice trembled with anguish, punctuated by sobs.

‚ÄúWait, what? Things are different now! You won‚Äôt be thrown to the giant beasts!‚Äù Fire moved closer, kneeling beside him. ‚ÄúHow long have you been hiding them?‚Äù

‚ÄúSince I went through metamorphosis… but I guess I always knew… I always feared them…‚Äù Wind‚Äôs voice was filled with despair.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay! Everything will be fine,‚Äù Fire assured him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here for you, and I‚Äôm sure the others will be, too.‚Äù Fire reached out to gently touch Wind‚Äôs shoulder, but as he did, he felt a sudden, violent pushback.

‚ÄúNo! You don‚Äôt understand! Lady Constant hates them! I‚Äôll pray to Lady Constant until they go away. You have to promise me that you will never tell anyone! No one can know!‚Äù Wind‚Äôs voice broke with anger and fear, tears streaming down his face.

They never spoke of it again. Fire respected Wind‚Äôs wish, but he felt that was the moment their friendship began to unravel. He struggled to understand someone unwilling to embrace their true identity. A goddess who instills such suffering, he thought, is not a goddess worthy of devotion.

As the years passed, Fire watched Wind‚Äîonce vibrant and cheerful‚Äîslowly consumed by bitterness. Fire found himself wishing Wind would reveal his hidden splendor, but that moment never came.

Looking back, Fire realized that being raised under the strict rules of the Great Order of Order meant that revealing Wind‚Äôs wings would risk everything‚Äîhis social status, his relationships, and the very foundation of his beliefs. It was a testament to Wind‚Äôs unwavering faith and commitment to Lady Constant.

Perhaps Fire was wrong to assume he knew who Wind truly was. Maybe he had erred in not accepting Wind‚Äôs choice. And yet, he couldn‚Äôt bring himself to be near the person Wind had become.

item.title: Labeland
item.description:
Meanwhile, in Some Dimension…

Navigating through the green hills, I’ve arrived at this place where giant label makers were placed. People would approach them, get a label on themselves, and proceed to the next label maker. The process would repeat endlessly. Some had their bodies completely covered.

On top of the hill, a figure without a single label observed the scene with a happy face. I sat by his side and asked, “What’s happening here?”

“They label themselves to find community. I used to be like that. One day, though, I took a shower and everything peeled off. When I went out, I had never been so well received. I noticed people approached me way more frequently. So I realized that while labels can help you find a community, they also alienate others. That’s why I don’t wear them anymore. I know who I am.”

item.title: Fire Defeats the Broken Thing
item.description:
Meanwhile in His Dimension

In Fire’s existence, something was always perpetually broken.

No matter how many times he tried to fix it, it would hold together only for a moment‚Äîbefore breaking again.

He examined the broken thing from every angle. “Why does it keep falling apart?” he wondered.

It shouldn‚Äôt have been broken, yet it was. Always in the way, always failing. “Was that why it was discarded so easily? Like someone else had already given up?”

It felt cursed‚Äî defiant, mocking, relentless.

He tried again and again‚Äîreinforcing, tightening, rearranging. Each time, it seemed to hold for a moment before crumbling again. “Maybe it‚Äôs just meant to stay broken,” he thought, staring at the scattered pieces.

But something about giving up felt worse. Fire‚Äôs frustration blazed like a furnace, consuming every ounce of patience he had left with each attempt. He even considered total and utter destruction.

Exhausted from the fight, he lay on the ground, defeated. “I can‚Äôt leave it like this,” he thought. “There has to be a way. Starting over would be far too costly.”

The solution he avoided lingered in the back of his mind. It was risky, and once done, there‚Äôd be no undoing it. For days, he hesitated, circling the idea like a moth to a flame.

After days of hesitation, Fire finally tried the one thing he had avoided. “I‚Äôve got nothing else to lose,” he said.

And then‚Äîwhat a glorious moment! For the first time, he felt like he truly understood the broken thing.

It had been held together by hacks and patches, but what it truly needed was a permanent solution.

The broken thing bore scars of countless repairs, but for the first time, it stood firm, resilient in its imperfection.

Fire sat back, a wave of relief washing over him. He felt a quiet sense of accomplishment.

“Finally,” he sighed. “What else do I need to fix?”

item.title: Giant Rat
item.description:
Meanwhile, in Some Dimension…

In the center of the castle, there was a giant, old, and dirty rat, surrounded by treasures of all kinds.

“It eats cool ideas and poops out old and lame ones. The more it eats, the fatter, lazier, and stinkier it gets.”

“Why do they keep feeding it?” I asked.

“It wasn‚Äôt always like that. Its poop was once fresh. People got too emotionally attached to it, and now they don’t want to address the stink.”

“Seems like a toxic relationship, huh?”

“They took care of it after its owner died, but things were never the same. These people… they don’t care about the quality of the poop, they only care that it’s still pooping.”

“They should end its suffering. It’s so dense that it’s warping this dimension.”

“I know, right? There’s only room for so many rats.”

“I think there’s still hope, though. I mean, for the little ones.”

“Yeah, me too.”

item.title: Your Reflection Isn't You
item.description:
Meanwhile, in Some Dimension…

I was walking through a colonnade, surrounded by what appeared to be shallow waters. In the distance, more colonnades stretched into the horizon, their reflections rippling in the water. Beyond them, the landscape was sparse‚Äîperhaps some small trees, but little else. The sunlight was direct and bright, as if it were around noon. Other people walked there too, though whether they were visitors or inhabitants was unclear.

As I passed a mirror, I caught a glimpse of my reflection. Or so I assumed. I hadn‚Äôt looked directly, just enough to register movement‚Äîa figure walking in step with me.

A few steps later, something felt off. A faint discomfort, like an itch in my thoughts.

I slowed. Turned back.

The mirror stood there, the figure inside moving just as I did. But the longer I looked, the stranger it became. The posture, the proportions‚Äîclose, but wrong. The face, familiar, yet undeniably not mine.

A tingling sensation ran from the tips of my toes, through my spine, all the way to the top of my head. The world flickered, as if the air itself had briefly warped. Columns swayed in a way stone shouldn‚Äôt, their reflections distorting independently of the water‚Äôs movement. And just like that, I knew.

I was dreaming.

Reality wavered, bending under the weight of my realization. I turned to the nearby people, eager to share my discovery. I had always wondered what those who inhabited dreams had to say. But instead, they only raised their eyebrows, their expressions edged with disdain, as if I were some lunatic disrupting their day.

item.title: Disposable
item.description:
Seating on the floor and resting her head against the bed, Lady Spiral desperately cried, her sobs echoing softly through the room. The Queen appeared in the doorway, her presence filling the space. “Oh honey, don’t cry. Mama is here for you,” she cooed, kneeling beside Spiral. She stroked her hair gently, fingers threading through the strands in a soothing rhythm, but nothing could stem Spiral’s grief. Her sobs continued, unrelenting.

Moments passed before the Queen spoke again, her voice a mix of sweetness and indifference. “You know, princes come and go. When you are Queen, you’ll meet hundreds of them in a single year.”

Spiral froze, her breath catching in her throat. She blinked, stunned, as the words sank in. “How do you know…?” she whispered, barely able to speak through the shock. Her voice trembled. “Y-You… sent me away…” Slowly, she pushed herself away from the Queen, stumbling as she stood, her body trembling in disbelief.

The Queen’s gaze hardened. What had once been tender now twisted into something colder, more calculating. Her lips thinned, eyes narrowing with a flicker of disgust. She could sense the challenge‚Äîone she had dreaded, but now knew was inevitable.

“You know, honey,” the Queen’s tone was sharp, dismissive, “I actually did you a favor. They die so easily, it’s best not to get too attached. They’re… disposable.”

Spiral froze. Disposable. The word echoed, hollow and damning. Her breath hitched, chest tightening as heat surged beneath her skin.

Her eyes widened, then narrowed, pupils shrinking to slits. Her jaw clenched, a sharp twitch in her cheek betraying the storm brewing inside. Fingers trembled, then curled into fists, nails biting into her palms.

A crackle split the air. Sparks danced at her fingertips. Her breaths grew shallow, trembling‚Äînot with shock, but with rage.

“Disposable?” Spiral’s voice cracked. Her aura flared around her, emitting sparks of electricity, wild and dark. Wings emerged from her back as she levitated. The room began to shift, reality itself warping under the weight of her power. Furniture and decorations rattled, shifting and bending as though the very space was bending to her will. Winds whipped through the chamber as shadows deepened, and the air crackled with the ominous charge of purple lightning. A bolt nearly struck the Queen, but she stood unmoved, unflinching.

Before Spiral’s fury could fully erupt, the Queen raised her hand. With a simple gesture, she absorbed all the chaotic energy swirling in the room into herself. The storm died in an instant, leaving Spiral drained and hollow, her body crumbling to the floor like a rag doll. Her eyes now stared blankly ahead. The room settled back into stillness, though it remained a mess‚Äîfurniture scattered, decorations askew, and the lingering aftermath of the storm evident in the disarray.

The Queen moved swiftly, appearing before Spiral in a blink, her hand gripping Spiral’s neck and slamming her against the wall. She lifted her effortlessly, holding her in place as Spiral’s feet dangled off the ground.

“Listen, honey,” the Queen hissed, her voice dripping with venom. “This is my Hive. Your little adventure could have destabilized everything. This is a game, and right now, it‚Äôs in our favor. Play by the rules, and you can enjoy the privileges. Step out of line, and you’ll lose everything.” She paused, her eyes narrowing further. “I am sparing you. You should be grateful no one else discovered your involvement.”

With that, she released Spiral, dropping her unceremoniously to the floor. Spiral crumpled, shattered within, her mind barely clinging to consciousness as the Queen turned and left her there, discarded like the “disposable” lives she had spoken of. The workers, having sensed the disturbance, watched in silence, but none dared to act. As the Queen hastily passed through them, her head down and one hand over her forehead, as though nursing a headache, she barked an order. “Clean up this mess!”

item.title: Lady Thread's Leap
item.description:
Meanwhile, in This Dimension…

Fire returns to an abandoned theme park, a place once filled with energy and laughter. The layout is unchanged, but the park feels empty, stripped of the life it once knew. Most of the attractions have been dismantled and sold for scrap, leaving only rusting remains. Nature, uninvited, has begun to reclaim the area, creeping over decaying rides and structures.

As he wanders through the silence, Fire encounters a girl. Like him, she seems drawn to the park for reasons they can barely explain. He doesn‚Äôt remember her, but she insists she remembers him. She wears a Japanese sailor school uniform, and her long braid swings behind her as she moves. Together, they spend the day exploring the desolate attractions, lost in the haze of forgotten memories.

At sunset, they stop at a bridge tangled in vines. She climbs up, balancing on the railing.

“Hey, get down! That’s dangerous!” Fire calls out, concern edging his voice.

“What? This?” she grins, then effortlessly does a cartwheel over the railings.

“Please, can you get down? You’re making me nervous!” he insists.

She laughs, eyes sparkling with mischief. “Give me your finger!”

“Huh?” Fire asks, confused.

Without a word, she kneels and takes his hand, pretending to tie a knot on his index finger. “You really don‚Äôt remember, do you?” she teases, her smile playful and knowing.

Leaning close, she whispers in his ear, “I‚Ä¶ am‚Ä¶ you.” Straightening up, she gazes out at the sunset. “Life is one long thread of thought.”

Then, with a mischievous grin, she says, “I have to go now. See you soon!” In a fluid, acrobatic move, she leaps backward off the bridge.

Fire‚Äôs hand lingers in the air where hers had been. His chest tightens as he watches her disappear into the void. He lunges forward, arm outstretched‚Äî

But there’s nothing. No splash. Just the rush of wind past him, carrying her final words into the emptiness.

item.title: Ant Hill
item.description:
Meanwhile, in This Dimension…

After school, on her way home, Zero crouched by an ant hill, watching as the tiny workers tirelessly carried pebbles out of their tunnels, each moving with purpose. A few feet away, she noticed hundreds of ants swarming around a lollipop, likely dropped by some careless kid earlier.

“They‚Äôre fascinating,” she murmured to herself.

She gently reached into a nearby puddle, trying to rescue an ant struggling to stay afloat.

“What are you doing?” a voice mocked from behind. It was Spiral, passing by on her way home.

Zero didn‚Äôt look up, her focus still on the ant. “It‚Äôs suffering,” she said softly. “I‚Äôd like to think that if I were in its situation, someone would rescue me too.”

Spiral squatted beside her, gracefully arranging her skirt as she sat. “They are fascinating,” she agreed.

Picking up a stick, Spiral began to poke the ant hill. A wave of panic surged through the colony as ants poured out of their tunnels, scattering in frantic disarray.

“Hey! What are you doing?! That‚Äôs mean!” Zero jumped to her feet, her voice filled with distress.

Spiral‚Äôs eyes sparkled with amusement. “What? Don‚Äôt you want to see how they react?”

item.title: Familiarity Fatigue
item.description:
Everything he could carry fit into that backpack. Fire leapt into his land sail vehicle, unfurled the sail, and pulled the rope tight against his chest. It was a serene, silent Dawn Day, with a gentle breeze brushing against his face. Before slipping on his goggles, he took one last look at the Hive, its mounds looming quietly in the distance.

“As a larva, the Hive felt endless‚Äîevery crevice a world, every sound a mystery. My first venture into the tunnels was thrilling, full of discovery. But now? It feels small, predictable. Maybe I‚Äôve changed, not the Hive.”

He checked his hammer at his belt, then ensured his cloth-wrapped sword‚Äîhis masterpiece‚Äîwas secure on the vehicle.

“The Art of Materialization… Once thrilling, now fleeting. Creations shrink as fast as they form. I worked through aching hands, fueled by excitement‚Äînow the ache lingers, even at rest. Have I lost the magic, or just overlooked the spark?”

As the wind carried him from the Hive, he adjusted his goggles and looked back one last time. “Did it change, or did I? Maybe with fresh eyes, it would feel vast again. For now, I can only wonder.”

item.title: The Day Before the Coronation
item.description:
Meanwhile, in That Dimension…

It was the Night Day just before the Coronation Ceremony. Feeling down, Zero sat on a bench on the Hive, quietly observing the frenetic preparations for the day ahead. The Hive buzzed with life, its intricate network of corridors glowing faintly with a soft amber hue, amplifying the sense of anticipation.

A strange girl sat beside her. She looked different, like an outsider. Her attire shimmered with colors that shifted with her movements, and on her head sat a peculiar “tiara” that, to Zero, seemed to whisper faint, ethereal music.

“Hey, you‚Äôre not from here, are you? How did you get in?” Zero asked, her voice hesitant but curious.

The girl tilted her head, as though the question didn‚Äôt quite make sense to her. ‚ÄúMe hear Hive People best music, whoop whoop! Show soon! Circuits go bouncy-bounce sparkles giggle pops!‚Äù she replied, her words an effervescent string of sound that felt more sung than spoken.

She opened her purse, revealing a collection of strange treats that shimmered like miniature galaxies. “Black whole bellyache,” she said, offering one to Zero.

Hesitant at first, but drawn in by the treat’s alluring scent and its swirling, otherworldly appearance, Zero took a bite. The flavors burst across her tongue in a kaleidoscope of sensations. A wave of dizziness hit her, and the world around her blurred and shifted.

She found herself transported to a barren wasteland under a pale, ashen sky. At its center stood a single, gnarled tree surrounded by a starving family. The scene felt raw and vivid, as if she were witnessing a memory.

The family harvested the tree‚Äôs peculiar, unappetizing fruit. Its taste was bitter, its texture strange and uninviting. Yet, it sustained them. Carefully, they gathered seeds to plant, nurturing the seedlings with the same care they gave each other.

The vision shifted, and Zero saw the fruit‚Äôs evolution. Over generations, the family selected the best fruits, slowly transforming it into something sweeter, brighter. The fruit spread to nearby villages, becoming a lifeline for many. It was made into jelly, pickled, turned into wine, and adapted in countless other ways.

As years passed, the fruit traveled across distant lands, its taste and form constantly reshaped by countless hands. Zero watched as it became a universal treasure, its origins a forgotten tale woven into the lives it had saved.

The vision faded, and Zero found herself back on the Hive. The faint hum of surrounding noise slowly reasserted itself, blending with the murmur of distant voices. Her hands trembled as tears streamed down her face, the lingering taste of the treat still dancing on her tongue, a vivid reminder of what she had seen.

She stared at the half-eaten treat, its shimmering surface now seeming to pulse with a quiet, inner light. “That fruit… its essence, its journey‚Äîit‚Äôs in this,” she whispered, her voice raw with awe and emotion. “What‚Äôs it called?”

‚ÄúMadame Astra‚Äôs Nebula Cupcakes, whoop whoop!‚Äù the girl chirped, her high-pitched, gleeful voice dancing like a musical refrain.

‚ÄúThis is… the most beautiful thing I‚Äôve ever tasted,‚Äù she whispered. Her voice quivered with emotion. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs exactly what I needed.‚Äù

“No sad, only zoom-zoom smiles!” the strange girl responded, her tone cheerful.

Zero stood, a faint smile on her lips and newfound determination lighting her eyes. ‚ÄúI have to go now. Thank you for this.‚Äù She paused, then added, ‚ÄúThe Hive can be dangerous for outsiders, so take care.‚Äù

The girl smiled and replied, ‚ÄúWhoop whoop!‚Äù

From a balcony on the Mound, Lady Thread and Lady Entanglement observed the scene through ornate binoculars.

“Millennium Whoop,” said Lady Entanglement, her voice steady, with a hint of intrigue.

Lady Thread‚Äôs fingers idly fiddled with invisible strands between them. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs her, isn‚Äôt it?‚Äù she said softly, a spark of excitement in her voice. ‚ÄúWhy is she here?‚Äù

item.title: Spiral
item.description:
On a Midnight Day, the Captain sat atop the Red Walker’s head, leaning against the beast’s thick fur for support. His usual determined, slightly stern expression remained fixed as he gripped the ropes for steering. In the distance, hundreds of legionaries marched in a synchronized mill formation, their footsteps a faint hum, mingling with the low murmur of voices carried by the wind.

The Captain removed his hat and placed it over his chest, his voice low with quiet sympathy. ‚ÄúPoor things,‚Äù he murmured.

‚ÄúWhat’s that? A ritual?‚Äù Fire‚Äôs voice broke the stillness. He stood behind the Captain, watching the distant figures.

The Captain glanced back. ‚ÄúHuh? First time seeing one of these? They don‚Äôt teach you about this on your Hive?‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe they do. I wasn‚Äôt paying attention.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs The Spiral,‚Äù the Captain said, turning back to the sight. ‚ÄúThey lost the vibe trail to their camp. Now they‚Äôre following each other‚Äôs vibes.‚Äù

‚ÄúLegionaries are so dumb. Seems simple to get out,‚Äù Fire scoffed.

The Captain turned sharply, his gaze hard. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not how they perceive it, Fire. You‚Äôre not immune to this! Any of us could end up there if we lose our sense of direction. Their reality has warped around them; right now, they‚Äôre trapped in cognitive dissonance. At first, they don‚Äôt even realize they‚Äôre lost. I don‚Äôt know how long these ones have been like this, but it can last for weeks‚Äîuntil everyone dies of exhaustion.‚Äù

A chill ran down Fire‚Äôs spine. ‚ÄúSo there‚Äôs no way out?‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs hope, but it‚Äôs rare. Very rare.‚Äù The Captain‚Äôs voice was grim. ‚ÄúAnd there‚Äôs nothing we can do. If you ever see one of these, don‚Äôt even think of getting close, or you‚Äôll be drawn into the same vibe! I mean it, Fire‚Äînot even a glance.‚Äù His tone softened slightly, but his words remained sharp. ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs strange you don‚Äôt know about this. It‚Äôs a key part of the foundation myth of the Hives.‚Äù

Fire frowned, vague memories stirring‚Äîa droning Hive teacher reciting the tale like it was some distant legend, far removed from reality. Now, it felt uncomfortably close.

The Captain broke the silence, his tone brusque. ‚ÄúWhy are you up here, anyway? Don‚Äôt you have anything better to do?‚Äù

item.title: Bargain
item.description:
The Master of Materialization had been a recurring customer of the Captain‚Äôs services for decades, yet their exchanges always carried a peculiar tension. From the top of the Giant Red Walker‚Äôs head, under the dim, shifting hues of a Night Day, their conversation took a strange turn.

‚ÄúI hear you‚Äôre the best Captain alive. Is that true?‚Äù the Master asked, his voice smooth, almost mocking.

The Captain barely glanced at him, his tone dismissive. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs just talk.‚Äù

‚ÄúI hear you can navigate any kind of beast,‚Äù the Master continued, undeterred.

The Captain crossed his arms, gaze fixed on the horizon. ‚ÄúRed Walkers, Feathered Mountains. Big or small, grounded or flying‚Äîit‚Äôs all the same in theory. But now, this is my ship.‚Äù He patted the Red Walker‚Äôs fur with a faint smile. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôll likely be her last Captain. She‚Äôs been our home for 1,600 years. I‚Äôm not leaving anytime soon.‚Äù

The Master leaned forward, his tone growing sly. ‚ÄúHow about‚Ä¶ Giant People-Eaters?‚Äù

The Captain‚Äôs head snapped toward him, his expression hardening. ‚ÄúBlasphemy! You must be mad! What exactly are you planning?‚Äù

The Master‚Äôs lips curled at the edges, his tone still light but carrying an undercurrent of something deeper. ‚ÄúI simply like to know what is possible,‚Äù he mused. ‚ÄúAnd I am a man who finds‚Ä¶ possibilities.‚Äù

The Captain exhaled sharply. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre playing with fire.‚Äù

The Master‚Äôs gaze remained steady, unbothered. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve made a habit of it,‚Äù he murmured. ‚ÄúAnd I always find a way, Captain. Doors open for me, even the locked ones.‚Äù

For the first time, the Captain felt something press against him‚Äînot physically, but as if the very space around the Master bent to his presence. The air felt heavier, charged with an unnatural stillness. He ignored it, but the unease lingered, refusing to leave.

The Master stepped closer, his shadow stretching unnaturally in the dim light. ‚ÄúYou see, Captain, I don‚Äôt just open doors. I rewrite the locks.‚Äù His grin widened, his confidence unshaken. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a very wealthy and powerful man, Captain. Wouldn‚Äôt it be nice if obstacles simply‚Ä¶ vanished?‚Äù

The Captain‚Äôs lip curled. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre sick. I don‚Äôt need your money or your tricks,‚Äù he spat. He could feel a whisper of doubt coil in his chest, but he crushed it. ‚ÄúI have all I need right here‚Äîmy home, my crew, my daughter, my family. Everything. A true Captain never leaves his ship.‚Äù

The Master‚Äôs smile faltered for a moment, but his unsettling presence only grew stronger. The air around them seemed to ripple, as if reality itself hesitated in his presence. His eyes gleamed with something dark, something the Captain felt but refused to acknowledge.

‚ÄúI always get what I want,‚Äù the Master said softly, almost a whisper. ‚ÄúAnd I always find a way, Captain. Don‚Äôt forget who you‚Äôre dealing with.‚Äù

Story Summaries:

Rooftop features an intimate conversation between two friends, Fire and Water. It‚Äôs a reflective and intimate story about growing up, facing uncertainties, and finding meaning in fleeting moments.

In Hacker, Lady Entanglement’s personality really shines through‚Äîit‚Äôs a fun little interaction with Fire, and I think you‚Äôre going to love her! The story plays with the idea that the universe itself may be a system open to modification, blending metaphysical speculation with hacker culture and a sense of whimsical mystery.

Beach Episode is the longest story so far! Fire and Water are joined by two new characters, Day and Night, as they embark on an adventure chasing a UFO. This one has a little bit of everything, and it‚Äôs set to be the most emotional chapter yet. It explores themes of transformation, pain, and connection, where Fire learns that true bonds require both vulnerability and resilience, as he struggles to accept the inevitable loss that comes with meaningful relationships.

These three stories are all part of Part 2 and are essential for understanding what‚Äôs going on. I saved them for last because they‚Äôre my favorites! They‚Äôll also more or less conclude the ‚Äúsetup‚Äù for the rest of the story. No turning back now‚ÄîI have to commit to these ideas!

Apartment Dimension I is also part of Part 2, but it could just as easily stand alone as a separate story! It features Fire, Lady Thread, Lady Entanglement, and Millennium Whoop living together in a NYC apartment. This one is by far the funniest story yet!

Finally, we return to Part 1 with Birth Ritual. This story is packed with worldbuilding and offers deep insight into the culture of the Hive People. It follows the Queen giving birth, as seen from Fire‚Äôs perspective.

Earlier, I mentioned updating weekly, but as the chapters grow longer, more complex, and more layered, I‚Äôm not sure I can maintain that pace. But as it stands, I need to focus on projects that actually bring in income.

New stories will be exclusive to Ko-fi subscribers for two weeks before becoming free on the Aetherway website. The good news is that the first tier (Whoop whoop!) is now only $1, and posts will also be available for a month to anyone who makes a one-time donation!

I‚Äôm really excited to share these stories with you, and I hope you enjoy the journey as much as I do! Your support‚Äîwhether through Ko-fi, comments, or simply following along‚Äîmeans the world to me. Every bit of encouragement fuels the Aetherway Project and keeps it going!

item.title: Is This The End?
item.description:
The Aetherway started as a way to promote my work, but it became something much deeper. I knew that cool designs alone wouldn‚Äôt be enough‚ÄîI needed something that truly resonated with people. So, I poured my soul into this project, and it‚Äôs been a rewarding experience. In the process, I‚Äôve discovered myself as a writer, and bringing these stories to life has been both fulfilling and healing. After years of relying solely on commissions, this has given me a creative space that feels like my own.

That said, rewarding doesn‚Äôt always mean successful. Getting people to actually support the project has been an uphill battle. I constantly remind people that they can help in multiple ways, yet the results are minimal. It can feel cold and lonely at times‚Äîeven expecting a comment feels like asking too much. Which is ironic, considering The Aetherway is all about connection.

I realize nobody asked for this, but then again‚Äîwho asks for anything in This Dimension? Sometimes, you don‚Äôt know you want something until you see it. People complain about the current uncreative landscape, but how can new projects thrive when they‚Äôre met with indifference? Right now, The Aetherway is just a sprout. But if we nurture it, it can grow into something huge‚Äîsomething we can look back on and say, “Hey, we build this.”

So, I‚Äôve been thinking‚Äîmaybe I should start paywalling new stories on my Ko-fi, at least temporarily. Maybe I should‚Äôve done this from the start, but I hesitated, weighing the trade-offs of reaching fewer people. Not that I expect comments to magically increase, but at least it would ensure some tangible support. That‚Äôs the reality of self-promotion nowadays‚Äîsometimes, you have to put a price on what you create, even when you wish you didn‚Äôt have to.

What do you think? Should I keep full access to new stories free, knowing they might not continue, or is a small paywall the right move to help The Aetherway grow?

item.title: Tonight‚Äôs Miracle
item.description:
Meanwhile, in This Dimension…

INTRO MUSIC

ANCHOR: Good evening, and welcome to Evening Report. Our top story tonight‚Äîa mysterious and inexplicable encounter at a local bar that has left patrons and the owner both in shock and disbelief.

[CUT TO SCENE: Footage of the bar, with neon lights flickering and empty stools. A lower-third banner reads: ‚ÄúMysterious Girl Pays It All‚Äù]

ANCHOR (V.O.): It started like any other evening at this small bar. Regulars sat at their usual spots, nursing their drinks and chatting with one another. But then, something happened that no one could have predicted.

[CUT TO: On-site correspondent standing in front of the bar. The reporter holds a microphone as they speak.]

REPORTER: Witnesses describe the girl as enchanting‚Äîalmost otherworldly. One patron insists she was in two places at once, sitting on a stool and standing by the jukebox simultaneously. Several noted that her clothes seemed to shift colors as she moved, catching light in impossible ways, as if reality itself couldn‚Äôt decide what she was wearing.

And it wasn‚Äôt just what she did‚Äîit was how she spoke. Words tumbled out in bursts of sound and rhythm. It was like a song you could feel as much as hear.

She tapped the jukebox and it played a song no one recognized‚Äîbut everyone knew the words.

Then, she stood up and announced:

[CUT TO: CCTV footage of the girl confidently standing on top of a table, arms wide open. The footage is silent.]

REPORTER (V.O.): She said, “Tonight is on me.”

[CUT BACK TO: The reporter.]

REPORTER: The bar erupted in celebration. Regulars who usually kept to themselves were suddenly laughing, dancing, and enjoying each other’s company like never before. The mood was infectious, and for hours, it seemed like nothing could go wrong.

[CUT TO: Interviews with the bar patrons, their voices filled with wonder as they reflect on the event.]

PATRON 1: When she shouted, ‘Tonight is on me,’ I thought she was just joking. But then… it was like everyone in the place suddenly came alive. I mean, some of us don‚Äôt even get along, but that night? We were all family. And don‚Äôt get me started on the dancing… I’ve never seen regulars get that wild. It was like we were all under her spell.

[CUT TO: A woman, who looks a bit confused, but thoughtful.]

PATRON 2: I don‚Äôt know… I‚Äôve been thinking about it all day. It wasn‚Äôt just the fun or the drinks‚Äîit was like she was connecting everyone. Like she was part of some bigger plan. Maybe she was some kind of angel, or… I don‚Äôt know. I woke up the next day and remembered every detail, but it felt like a dream. A good dream, though.

[CUT TO: A man leaning against a fence outside the bar, arms crossed, skeptical but bemused.]

PATRON 3: I didn‚Äôt see any girl. I left early. But when I got home, my wallet had more cash than I remember.

[CUT TO: Footage of the bar as patrons laugh and reminisce, the camera panning over empty chairs and glasses.]

REPORTER (V.O.): However, when the night ended, and the bar‚Äôs owner went to collect the bill, things took a strange turn. The girl had disappeared‚Äîvanished without a trace. Her glass never emptied, and no one saw her drink.

[CUT TO: Interview with the bar owner, who is visibly upset.]

OWNER: I couldn‚Äôt believe it. She was right there, and then… nothing. But what really got me? No one had actually ordered anything. No drinks, no snacks, nothing was consumed!

[CUT TO: The owner pacing inside the bar.]

REPORTER (V.O.): The owner, initially furious, soon discovered something even more baffling. Minutes later, he received a call from his bank. The debts he‚Äôd been struggling to pay off? They were all mysteriously cleared.

[CUT TO: The owner breaking down in front of the camera, overcome with emotion.]

OWNER: I don‚Äôt understand how. I was drowning in debt. And then… she shows up? I don‚Äôt know what happened, but… she did something.

[CUT TO: The bar‚Äôs empty stools, the neon sign flickering again.]

REPORTER: The bartender joked that her tab would bankrupt them‚Äîhe didn‚Äôt realize it was already paid. Some say the air shimmered when she vanished‚Äîand left behind the faint smell of burned sugar, hanging just long enough to notice. But the question remains: who was this girl, and what happened that night? Was she a good Samaritan, or something more… supernatural?

[BACK TO STUDIO: Anchor at the desk.]

ANCHOR: A mysterious benefactor? A trick of the mind? Or something more? What‚Äôs clear is that this mysterious girl has left a lasting impact on everyone she touched.

And as for the bar owner… he may not know who saved his livelihood. But in this town, she won‚Äôt soon be forgotten.

She may have vanished… but her tab remains open ‚Äî in the hearts of this town.

ANCHOR (smiling slightly): In other local news‚Äîa neighborhood cat has been nominated for ‚ÄúEmployee of the Month‚Äù at a hardware store in Eastview.
